instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1502: What is A1502? A1502 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2014, Late 2013, Early 2015 with EMC 2875, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3476, 820-3536, 820-4924..
definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.BKLT_EN_R: What is BKLT_EN_R? This signal enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. The “_R” suffix means that the signal is asserted when it is high, as in 3.3v, which is the opposite of the “_L”  suffix.
definitions.BKLT_SD: What is BKLT_SD? BKLT_SD is a pin of the LED driver that goes to the voltage divider that feeds the gate of the transistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H and the backlight circuit. The LED driver will short this pin to ground when backlight circuit is ready to turn on. Prerequisites are 1) it is told to turn on via enable signal, the screen has communicated with the LED driver 2) current sensing circuit is working 3) does not detect an over-current situation such as the backlight power rail being shorted to ground.
definitions.BKLT_SCL: What is BKLT_SCL? BKLT_SCL is an I2C signal clock line between the LED driver that creates the LCD backlight power rail that powers the backlight in the screen and the screen. The screen needs to speak to the LED driver on this line before backlight voltage will be created..
definitions.BKLT_SDA: What is BKLT_SDA? BKLT_SDA is a data line between the LCD screen and the LED driver. This data line cannot short to ground. If it does, the screen cannot talk to the LED driver, and the LED driver will not allow the circuit to produce a backlight..
definitions.3V3_S0: What is 3V3_S0? Abbreviation for PP3V3_S0, a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.I2C_BKLT_SDA: What is I2C_BKLT_SDA? I2C_BKLT_SDA is a data line between the LCD screen and the LED driver. This data line cannot short to ground. If it does, the screen cannot talk to the LED driver, and the LED driver will not allow the circuit to produce a backlight..
definitions.R7050: What is R7050? Current sense shunt resistor for the battery, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 17/18 on ISL6259 should give you 2.02 ohms. .
definitions.R7052: What is R7052? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.EDP_BKLT_PWM: What is EDP_BKLT_PWM? EDP_BKLT_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage... no image, but boots when Magsafe plugged in
threads.message:
TLDR - Early 2015 MBP Retina was dropped and had liquid damage as well. When plugged in it turns itself on until manually forced off. No display and no external on hdmi as well. 

Long story, bought a 13" <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Early 2015 and figured it had been dropped based on the listing. Little did I know it was dropped and had liquid damage in the corner near the lcd connector. The indicator in the middle of the board wasn't triggered. It arrived and I plugged the power in and it turned on by itself. 

I'm assuming a short somewhere, but the screen stayed pitch black. I should have tried the flashlight trick to see if the backlight was out, but already had the board out by the time I remembered that as I wanted to try a known working board I had in it. The other board worked fine with the magsafe and also the screen obviously. 

I've checked the board and the only thing I can come up with so far is a faulty FDC638APZ IC but still waiting for the chips to come in. So, I'm not sure where to go from here on the magsafe triggering the laptop on. Was considering putting it in my ultrasonic to clean it up before I get started again tracking down the issue. 

What do you guys think?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage... no image, but boots when Magsafe plugged in
threads.message:
"a faulty FDC638APZ IC "
You should mention schematic position, not component model.
Then we can make more exact idea about what you talk...

Test the board alone on the desk, only charger connected.
Need one USB device, if you get voltage on the CPU coils. to check for USB activity.
Dropped board is always nightmare; adding liquid spill, you are probably wasting time on it.
As is your personal machine, you can gain experience with it at least...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage... no image, but boots when Magsafe plugged in
threads.message:
Thank you for the information. I will try to do better. I am very new to doing apple logic boards. I've only done game consoles and other handheld devices. 

I am using a good / working logic board to compare to the bad one to help me with readings as I'm a novice at best when it comes to reading schematics. 

The biggest difference I'm seeing right now is at <TRANSISTOR>Q7701</TRANSISTOR> at the 3rd pin from the left on the bottom and at <TRANSISTOR>Q7700</TRANSISTOR> at pin 6 (.477) as it doesn't match Pin 1 at <CAPACITOR>C7711</CAPACITOR> (97.3) like Pin 6 (145.6) matches Pin 1 (145.6) on the good board.

I'm using a pretty cheap multimeter, but I started with <TRANSISTOR>Q7701</TRANSISTOR> and backtracked through and got to <CAPACITOR>C7711</CAPACITOR>.

[B][U]The bad board shows:[/U][/B]

At <TRANSISTOR>Q7701</TRANSISTOR>
In boardview it shows only a 5 at the bottom of the chip for the pins, but from left to right the readings for the 4 pins are. 
1st pin = 97.3, 2nd pin = 2.08, 3rd pin = 97.3, 4th pin = .47 (The 3rd pin here matches the first pin, but on the good board, the 3rd pin matches the 4th pin.) 

At <TRANSISTOR>Q7700</TRANSISTOR>
Pin 3 = 86.2
Pin 2 = 2.05
Pin 1 = .475
Pin 5 = 2.10
Pin 6 = .477

At <CAPACITOR>C7711</CAPACITOR>
Pin 1 = 97.3


[B][U]The good board shows: [/U][/B]

At <TRANSISTOR>Q7701</TRANSISTOR>
From left to right, 1st pin = 145.6, 2nd pin = 1.92, 3rd pin = .53, 4th pin = .53

At <TRANSISTOR>Q7700</TRANSISTOR>
Pin 3 = 85.7
Pin 2 = 148.3
Pin 1 = 1.86
Pin 5 = 1.84
Pin 6 = 145.6

At <CAPACITOR>C7711</CAPACITOR>
Pin 1 = 145.6 

I hope this helps even just a bit to helping get me going in the right direction.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage... no image, but boots when Magsafe plugged in
threads.message:
"In boardview it shows only a 5 at the bottom of the chip for the pins, but from left to right ..."
You make the things to look more complicated than they are!
Use signal names from schematic/boardview; this way avoid any confusion.
You do NOT need to mention any space direction, you are not examined for driver license here.
Our help is based on the information provided by you; so be more clearest posible, please.

As for example,
"At <TRANSISTOR>Q7701</TRANSISTOR>
From left to right, 1st pin = 145.6 "
there is in fact pin 4/<TRANSISTOR>Q7701</TRANSISTOR>, which MUST be mentioned as <SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_FET_DRV_R</SIGNAL>.
I have no idea if you posted a value measured on ohm scale, or diode scale (expected).
ALWAYS start measuring in diode scale, red probe at ground; sometime need to invert probes, for second reading!

On the other side, I wonder how can you get different readings in the same line¡¿?!
"2nd pin = 2.08, 3rd pin = 97.3, 4th pin = .47
----------------------------
2nd pin = 1.92, 3rd pin = .53, 4th pin = .53"
There should be <SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_SW</SIGNAL>, if your space reference is correct.
I don't talk about board differences.
In the same board, these three pins MUST get same reading; as all are connected to the same rail.

"Need one USB device, if you get voltage on the CPU coils. to check for USB activity. "
Do NOT waste the time searching for image/backlight, if you do not get voltage on CPU VCORE coils (L7310/20).
USB activity is also required to be confirmed first...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage... no image, but boots when Magsafe plugged in
threads.message:
[I][QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 60232, member: 682"]
"In boardview it shows only a 5 at the bottom of the chip for the pins, but from left to right ..."
You make the things to look more complicated than they are!
Use signal names from schematic/boardview; this way avoid any confusion.
You do NOT need to mention any space direction, you are not examined for driver license here.
Our help is based on the information provided by you; so be more clearest posible, please.

As for example,
"At <TRANSISTOR>Q7701</TRANSISTOR>
From left to right, 1st pin = 145.6 "
there is in fact pin 4/<TRANSISTOR>Q7701</TRANSISTOR>, which MUST be mentioned as <SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_FET_DRV_R</SIGNAL>.
I have no idea if you posted a value measured on ohm scale, or diode scale (expected).
ALWAYS start measuring in diode scale, red probe at ground; sometime need to invert probes, for second reading!

On the other side, I wonder how can you get different readings in the same line¡¿?!
"2nd pin = 2.08, 3rd pin = 97.3, 4th pin = .47
----------------------------
2nd pin = 1.92, 3rd pin = .53, 4th pin = .53"
There should be <SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_SW</SIGNAL>, if your space reference is correct.
I don't talk about board differences.
In the same board, these three pins MUST get same reading; as all are connected to the same rail.

"Need one USB device, if you get voltage on the CPU coils. to check for USB activity. "
Do NOT waste the time searching for image/backlight, if you do not get voltage on CPU VCORE coils (L7310/20).
USB activity is also required to be confirmed first...
[/QUOTE][/I]

As stated before, the computer boots to the chime even on the bad board, the screen is black with no hdmi external. 

I wanted to first find out how to fix the fact that when you connect an ac adapter to it the computer boots by itself. 

Then I wanted to find out how to restore the image/backlight. 

That's it. I was hoping someone might have seen this before or just know already and say oh, you should look in this area for a cap or fuse to be blown which is causing it to boot immediately when connecting the ac adapter. 

You can clearly tell, that I'm not an expert at this, but damnit I'm willing to try and learn it. I have 10+ years of service experience with a fortune 100 company on the software side of things, but not on the hardware component side. As a hobby, I've repaired boards with damaged traces or bad caps in game consoles, but half the time I couldn't tell you the difference between a resistor and a diode by looking at a board let alone what they do without googling it.  

Until I got this bad board, I've never even opened up boardview. All I've done is replace them entirely and assign the serial numbers to the boards. That's it. I want to learn how to do it and I've always learned hands-on.

I'm sorry, I'm not using the right terminology. I'm sorry I'm not saying things the right way. I'm sorry I'm not providing the information that all you guys are used to hearing and sharing with each other in certain verbiage. 

I lost my damn job, because of this pandemic. I've been trying to pick up work doing repairs for people and that is how I got stuck with this board. I'm trying my best with what littles skills and tools that I've got. 

I'm sorry.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage... no image, but boots when Magsafe plugged in
threads.message:
"No display and no external on hdmi as well "
That is the reason I asked about USB activity.
Missing internal and external video at same time, looks more like stuck board.

"As stated before, the computer boots to the chime even on the bad board "
NO, you've mentioned about ANOTHER working board, tested in the same case.
"The other board worked fine with the magsafe and also the screen obviously "

I'm really sorry if you got annoyed, was not my intention.
I just wanted to mark your wrong assumptions.
If you consider that is not for you help, dismiss such advise.

We try to start again.
First confirm USB activity on the first (bad) board.
Chime is not always sufficient.; board can get stuck after chime, before sending any image.
You've reported missing internal/external video at same time and is not too much reason to suspect a problem with backlight.

"I wanted to first find out how to fix the fact that when you connect an ac adapter to it the computer boots by itself. "
Not first, nor last.
I didn't say anything about that before, as it is normal behavior for any iCore MacBook.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage... no image, but boots when Magsafe plugged in
threads.message:
I think it might be your word usage and the use of your CAPS as it comes across as you scolding/yelling at me, when all I'm trying to do is seek some help. On top of that I am also having trouble understanding your English at times as well. It is very blunt and brash, but please understand that I do appreciate the fact that you've taken time to at least reply to me when no one else has. 

As you said, let's start again.

Could you please elaborate on what you mean by stuck board? As the term stuck is very vague. 

I will test for usb activity and voltage on the cpu coils and get back to you with that.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage... no image, but boots when Magsafe plugged in
threads.message:
Sorry, english is not my native language.
Is on third place, after romanian and spanish.

We have to distinguish somehow between working boards and boards turned on.
Not any board which turns on, also works.
If we get any voltage from S4 to S0 state, that board is turned on; S5 state corresponds to off state.
If we miss some important voltage from S4 to S0 state, the board can stay on, but will not work properly; its behavior will depend by missing volage.
Hearing the chime is sign the board really boots, but it can get blocked in some point; just before getting video, for example.
If you see Caps Lock LED reaction for example, that means is not stuck; that board really works.
You can have then a problem with image/backlight.
When we repair a board alone on the desk, the best way to test is using an USB device; many times an USB mouse is good enough (not always).

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage... no image, but boots when Magsafe plugged in

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage... no image, but boots when Magsafe plugged in
threads.message:
VCORE looks good.
Do you get USB activity now?
Disconnect/reconnect USB mouse when board is turned on; mouse get steady light again?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage... no image, but boots when Magsafe plugged in

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage... no image, but boots when Magsafe plugged in
threads.message:
Seems that you now have USB activity.
Test for external video, if the board is out of chassis.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage... no image, but boots when Magsafe plugged in
threads.message:
No external video on both DP ports on bad board.

Tested same setup and getting signal from good board.

So definitely no external video signal being sent to the monitor on bad board.

Yes, the board is out of the chassis.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage... no image, but boots when Magsafe plugged in
threads.message:
If there is USB activity for sure, you have a problem with Intel graphics.
And shouldn't be related only with internal, or external video outputs, as both are missing.

Did you take a photo of the liquid affected areas, before cleaning the board?
Some return from backlight voltage could have been killed the iGPU.
When you start the board with internal LCD connected, check for voltage at <RESISTOR>R8320</RESISTOR> pads.
You should also get voltage there in the first few seconds at least, even without LCD.
Keep the multimeter probe connected there when turn on the board; especially when hear the chime...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage... no image, but boots when Magsafe plugged in
threads.message:
Haven't put the board in the ultrasonic yet, Crest sent me the wrong one and it's too small. 

Finally got it under the scope and there is heavy corrosion inside both display ports and only the liquid damage indicator by the lcd connector is activated. The others are still white. It's like someone dipped the corner of the laptop in water near the lcd connector. 

I'll do the other tests later tonight or tomorrow and get back to you.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage... no image, but boots when Magsafe plugged in
threads.message:
Well... I went piece by piece through the board through the scope and found corrosion also on one other little piece and apparently a very important one as after I scraped the corrosion off and checked for continuity external video has been restored with a question mark folder showing :D 

I think it's the power delivery system for the video maybe? Not sure since I don't read schematics obviously. Going to put it back in the chassis and test again.

I'll attach a pic from board view of the questionable point on the board.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage... no image, but boots when Magsafe plugged in
threads.message:
Okay another update. 

External Video is only working via the DisplayPort. Also, tested the IO board for the USB and HDMI and no signal coming from the HDMI port and no USB activity either.

Going to try and figure it out while waiting for your feedback

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage... no image, but boots when Magsafe plugged in
threads.message:
Seems that you had corrosion on <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> circuit.
<TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> can be removed to bypass similar problem; is just a redundant protection.

Onboard USB port doesn't work too?
Did you connect the both cables between MLB and RIO boards?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage... no image, but boots when Magsafe plugged in
threads.message:
Nope, I was an idiot and did not connect both cables to the RIO board. Now USB and HDMI work as well. 

Still no internal display. Put in the good board and I can see the cracked lcd display. Put in the bad board and no display at all. 

What next? Backlight display?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage... no image, but boots when Magsafe plugged in
threads.message:
Image should appear first.
To avoid any artifact, or improper image on the display, the backlight appears with a small delay.

Do the mentioned tests about internal LCD output...
"When you start the board with internal LCD connected, check for voltage at <RESISTOR>R8320</RESISTOR> pads.
You should also get voltage there in the first few seconds at least, even without LCD.
Keep the multimeter probe connected there when turn on the board; especially when hear the chime"

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage... no image, but boots when Magsafe plugged in
threads.message: Getting 5v on the pads at <RESISTOR>R8320</RESISTOR>

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage... no image, but boots when Magsafe plugged in
threads.message:
If voltage is stable, then must have voltage at <SIGNAL>LCD_HPD_CONN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL>; is better to confirm.
You should also have image on internal LCD, check with flashlight.

Now check <SIGNAL>BKLT_EN_R</SIGNAL> and volatge at both pins of <DIODE>D7710</DIODE>; LCD connected, of course.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage... no image, but boots when Magsafe plugged in
threads.message:
Voltage is stable on pad 1. Voltage starts stable on pad 2 then fluctuates for a 2-3 seconds then becomes stable again and stays at 5v. Happens exact same way every boot.

LCD is too cracked to see any image. Even when good board is in the only thing I can see is just 2-3 cracks of light can't even see the little folder with question mark. 

On <DIODE>D7710</DIODE> - Pin 2 is .005 and Pin 1 is .023 while internal lcd is connected. That is no good I'm assuming.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage... no image, but boots when Magsafe plugged in
threads.message:
"On <DIODE>D7710</DIODE> - Pin 2 is .005 and Pin 1 is .023"
Diode mode to ground?
I hope you've disconnected power first.

BTW, I was asking for voltage at <DIODE>D7710</DIODE>...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage... no image, but boots when Magsafe plugged in
threads.message:

Diode mode to ground?
I hope you've disconnected power first.

BTW, I was asking for voltage at <DIODE>D7710</DIODE>...
[/QUOTE]


That was voltage at <DIODE>D7710</DIODE>. Power was connected. :(

I thought you wanted it to be powered on since we just checked voltage on <RESISTOR>R8320</RESISTOR> with power on. Sorry. 

Pin2 was .005 volts and pin1 was .023 volts. NOT diode mode. That's why I was assuming it was bad since not that many volts were showing on ppvin and out.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage... no image, but boots when Magsafe plugged in
threads.message:
Correct, I wanted voltage, but your values look more than diode mode; 3 decimals used for that usually.
For voltage, you could write just 0V, no differenece.

<SIGNAL>BKLT_EN_R</SIGNAL> still not posted.

Please, do note quote an entire post visible few centimeters above...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage... no image, but boots when Magsafe plugged in
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>BKLT_EN_R</SIGNAL> at <RESISTOR>R7742</RESISTOR> is 100.7 
<SIGNAL>BKLT_EN_R</SIGNAL> at <CAPACITOR>C7742</CAPACITOR> is 100.7
<SIGNAL>BKLT_EN_R</SIGNAL> at Pin 17 on <CHIP>U7700</CHIP> is 100.7

I no longer have the good board, so I was not able to compare, should there be a component at <CAPACITOR>C7742</CAPACITOR>? Cause it is just an empty pad? I attached best pic I could get. I thought R was for resistor and C for capacitor, but there is no capacitor at <CAPACITOR>C7742</CAPACITOR> I can see.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage... no image, but boots when Magsafe plugged in
threads.message:
All the components marked as "NO STUFF", are not present on the board.

Need the voltage at <SIGNAL>BKLT_EN_R</SIGNAL>; one point is sufficient...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage... no image, but boots when Magsafe plugged in
threads.message:
Okay, so I wanna clear something up... you asked previously "When you start the board with internal LCD connected, check for voltage at <RESISTOR>R8320</RESISTOR> pads." 

Boardview shows <RESISTOR>R8320</RESISTOR> as a 4 pin pad as I took a screenshot of, but when I look at the board it looks like pins 1 and 2 are a bridged pad to 3 and 4. Unless the 2 tiny pads above them are 3 and 4. 

Please see comparison pics and let me know which letter is right. A or B.

I'm assuming A is right.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage... no image, but boots when Magsafe plugged in
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R8320</RESISTOR> is not placed on the board, so all 4 pads are tied together; for this reason I said "pads", not "pins".

No reason to replace <TRANSISTOR>Q7700</TRANSISTOR>, if <SIGNAL>BKLT_SD</SIGNAL> is not 0V.
Try known good full LCD assembly; must be from 2015.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage... no image, but boots when Magsafe plugged in
threads.message:
So what are the two small points above the pads that I marked 3 and 4 in image A?

Cause I don't have another panel to try. If I got the board working then I would've spent the money on another panel but if I can't get the board working then I'm not spending 300-400 on a good panel.

When I connected the good board before sending it back it showed the backlight and this one doesn't still so that means something is still wrong with this one.

I think I have to give up then at this point. :(

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage... no image, but boots when Magsafe plugged in

<RESISTOR>R7733</RESISTOR> = pin 2 = 0v

how many volts should <CAPACITOR>C8354</CAPACITOR> be? I’m only getting 1.47v

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage... no image, but boots when Magsafe plugged in
threads.message:
If you get 3V at <SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL>, internal LCD is detected and probably the image is there; but not visible on the cracked screen.
Until <SIGNAL>BKLT_SD</SIGNAL> gets 0V, you cannot get any voltage at <DIODE>D7710</DIODE>.
Do you still have 3V at <SIGNAL>BKLT_EN_R</SIGNAL>?

If you got backlight with another 4924 board on this LCD, then the problem is in the actual board.

"So what are the two small points above the pads that I marked 3 and 4 in image A?"
Are the pads for Kelvin connection lines of Isense, not used in this case; directly connected to pins 1 & 2 respectively.

<SIGNAL>BKLT_SD</SIGNAL> <CHIP>U7700</CHIP> at Pin 11 = 12.4v
<SIGNAL>BKLT_SD</SIGNAL> <RESISTOR>R7702</RESISTOR> at Pin 2 = 12.4v

No, I no longer have 3v at <SIGNAL>BKLT_EN_R</SIGNAL>. Now says 0v.

threads.message:
Please pay more atention wgen you work.
We need to be sure about all posted values.
Pins 1 & 3 of <CHIP>U8300</CHIP> are tied together, like in schematic.

Do you really have 0V at all <CHIP>U8310</CHIP> connections?
Pin 1/A1 is connected directly to <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL> (<CAPACITOR>C8308</CAPACITOR>)....

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage... no image, but boots when Magsafe plugged in
threads.message: Sorry about that. I thought I was making contact with the pins but it turns out I wasn't. Thought my probes were small enough as they are tiny but not tiny enough to fit underneath after all. Yes all the components around it are getting power. Need to find smaller probes.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage... no image, but boots when Magsafe plugged in
threads.message:
Why try to make contact underneatch the chip?
Even on bigger QFN chips, you can easy make a short between pins.

ALWAYS measure touching the pins of surrounded components connected to the chip pin you want to test.
Use schematic/boardview to find proper test point.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage... no image, but boots when Magsafe plugged in
threads.message: Wow, that is cool. Didn't know you could get spare boards for macbooks. I get donor boards for my game consoles so I guess that makes sense. Only problem is not knowing what is good and bad on the boards...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage... no image, but boots when Magsafe plugged in
threads.message:
They remove all RAM chips and CPU.
SMC is always in place and the only option to get SMC replacment; because it has firmware and is board dependant.
Lot of MOSFETs, caps and other small chips...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage... no image, but boots when Magsafe plugged in
threads.message:
That is awesome. I'll order some. I always read the most reliable boards were somewhere around 2015, but not sure. I think they said non-retina too, but any one I see on ebay always are retina. 

By the way, I'm pretty positive that one of the issues, if not the main issue is the LCD connector. I say that because when I went to look at the video cable as you told me to do I noticed that on one side it looked like some plastic was missing. I looked inside the connector and a chunk of it had melted together inside the connector. Probably when the water hit it I think. I'll order a couple just in case something sets it off again to melt it. 

So, going to order the connector now to get it here the fastest. Going to be later this week that I post an update at the soonest.

Thanks again for all your help so far. I'll talk to you later this week or early next week.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage... no image, but boots when Magsafe plugged in
threads.message:
Remember I never had an image on the internal lcd. All I saw before on the cracked screen was the backlight working when I still had the good board. I was never able to see the image because the screen was cracked too much. 

I did have an image before, but I only had an image only on the hdmi port and the display ports.

The screen I ordered was for an early 2015 retina <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, I'm assuming it is 100% compatible.

Once I replaced the lcd connector and the replacement screen came in, I went back through everything you told me the first time. I got to where you told me to check the voltage at <DIODE>D7710</DIODE> pins from before. There was 0V on <DIODE>D7710</DIODE>. So then you said, "With 0V on <SIGNAL>BKLT_SD</SIGNAL>, you should have voltage on <DIODE>D7710</DIODE>; post both pins voltage. " But now I have 12.4V on <SIGNAL>BKLT_SD</SIGNAL>. 

Now you are saying that <SIGNAL>BKLT_EN_R</SIGNAL> is high... Is <SIGNAL>BKLT_SD</SIGNAL> the same as <SIGNAL>BKLT_EN_R</SIGNAL>? 

Cause I didn't check <SIGNAL>BKLT_EN_R</SIGNAL> voltage... 

I'm really confused now... and so close to giving up and going back to fixing game consoles. It was so much easier. :(

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage... no image, but boots when Magsafe plugged in
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_PSR_EN</SIGNAL> (so <SIGNAL>BKLT_EN_R</SIGNAL> too) must be high and <SIGNAL>BKLT_SD</SIGNAL> must be low; different signals, but directly related.

Backlight also depends by the communicacion between PCH, LCD and <CHIP>U7701</CHIP>; two distinct buses, =<SIGNAL>I2C_TCON_SCL</SIGNAL>/SDA and <SIGNAL>I2C_BKLT_SCL</SIGNAL>/SDA.

Be sure to always have 3V at <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0_EDP_R</SIGNAL> and 5V at pins 28-30 of J8300 (at least few seconds).

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage... no image, but boots when Magsafe plugged in
threads.message:
I have 3.3v at <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0_EDP_R</SIGNAL> and I have 5V at 28-30 of J8300.

I started looking at the current sense and looking at boardview vs the schematic, which I can't read very well, but I think boardview and the schematic shows there should be a <CHIP>U5450</CHIP>. On my board, I don't have a <CHIP>U5450</CHIP>, I only have 6 pads and half a solder point is missing on pin 6 and solder on pins 1 and 2 look terrible.

Schematic does not say "no stuff" for <CHIP>U5450</CHIP> that I can see.

Is <CHIP>U5450</CHIP> missing?

BTW I think someone worked on this board before I got it... I say that because there's just some other weird stuff I've seen already. Scratch marks on the PCB etc.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage... no image, but boots when Magsafe plugged in
threads.message:
<CHIP>U5450</CHIP> definitely not used.
There are few BOM options mentioned on schematic.

"I have 5V at 28-30 of J8300"
Is it steady?
If yes, <SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL> must be high and image present.

Post voltage and diode mode to ground on both I2C mentioned buses; wirh LCD connected.

Is  <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_PSR_EN</SIGNAL>  still missing?
<SIGNAL>EDP_PANEL_PWR_OR_PSR_EN</SIGNAL> seems to be present...

threads.message:
Yeah the 5V is steady at 28-30. <SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL> is at 3.3V

<SIGNAL>I2C_TCON_SCL</SIGNAL> or SDA - couldn't be found in boardview

<SIGNAL>I2C_BKLT_SCL</SIGNAL> = 5V and 1.84
<SIGNAL>I2C_BKLT_SDA</SIGNAL> = 3.3V and 1.82

<SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_PSR_EN</SIGNAL> = 3.3V

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage... no image, but boots when Magsafe plugged in
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>I2C_BKLT_SCL</SIGNAL> = 5V and 1.84
<SIGNAL>I2C_BKLT_SDA</SIGNAL> = 3.3V and 1.82"
You should get same voltage on both lines; check w/ and w/o LCD connected.
Be sure all 4 resistors <RESISTOR>R7750</RESISTOR>-53 are good.

"<SIGNAL>I2C_TCON_SCL</SIGNAL> or SDA - couldn't be found in boardview"
Seeing which connector pins are, easy to find them on boardview.
Sometime Apple doesn't keep identical signal names on boardview, like in schematic!

And with no LCD connected:
<SIGNAL>I2C_BKLT_SCL</SIGNAL> = 1.9
<SIGNAL>I2C_BKLT_SDA</SIGNAL> = 1.65

Both of those pads were of the 3 damaged and needed jumper wires.

and 

l2c-<SIGNAL>TCON_SCL</SIGNAL> = 3.3v and 1.77
l2c-<SIGNAL>TCON_SCA</SIGNAL> = 3.3v and 1.77

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage... no image, but boots when Magsafe plugged in
threads.message:
You should get similar values on both lines, you've posted a big difference.
That could be the reason of no backlight; as it is controlled through <SIGNAL>I2C_BKLT_SCL</SIGNAL>/SDA bus.
Are the last values taken with LCD connected?
In such case, pot voltages without LCD too.

<RESISTOR>R7050</RESISTOR>/51 must be 0 ohm and <RESISTOR>R7052</RESISTOR>/53 2.4K.

Sorry for misstyping, I meant SCL, not SCKA.
I can only use aprox 60% of my eyes...

I will get you the other measurements this evening. 

Thanks again for all your help

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage... no image, but boots when Magsafe plugged in
threads.message:
Internal LCD is connected through eDP (Embedded Display Port), which is not related with external DP going through Thunderbolt.

As <SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL> stays high, and you get steady 5V at pins 28-30, PCH detects internal LCD correctly.
Very likely image is there, but not easy to detect.

Think what you did on the board, recheck all your job.
You had correct <SIGNAL>BKLT_SDA</SIGNAL> with 0V before.

The big difference on <SIGNAL>I2C_BKLT_SCL</SIGNAL>/SDA lines blocks the backlight now.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage... no image, but boots when Magsafe plugged in
threads.message:
Well, I went back to check my work and as I was checking continuity on the lcd connector pins, it looks like i have a short to ground on <SIGNAL>I2C_BKLT_SCL</SIGNAL>.

Going to have to backtrack and try to find it. I'll try to tomorrow as it isn't my work as I removed the lcd connector and jumper wires and the short was still there.

Going to sleep it's been a long day.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage... no image, but boots when Magsafe plugged in
threads.message: So the short was bothering me. Backtracked it to <CHIP>U7700</CHIP>. Removed <CHIP>U7700</CHIP> and the short was gone. Gonna order a replacement.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage... no image, but boots when Magsafe plugged in
threads.message:
<CHIP>U7700</CHIP> replaced and short is now gone. 

<SIGNAL>L2C_BKLT_SCL</SIGNAL> = 5V
<SIGNAL>I2C_BKLT_SDA</SIGNAL> = 5V (was 3.3v)

<RESISTOR>R7752</RESISTOR>/53 are not 2.4K they are 1.59k
<RESISTOR>R7750</RESISTOR>/01 are 0.3 ohm

still no backlight

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage... no image, but boots when Magsafe plugged in
threads.message:
"<RESISTOR>R7752</RESISTOR>/53 are not 2.4K they are 1.59k"
Is normal to get lower value indications for onboard measurments.

An o-scope can show if there is activity on <SIGNAL>I2C_BKLT_SCL</SIGNAL>/SDA and  <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL> lines when backlight keys are pressed.
At least check if <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL> DC level varies.

<SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL> stays high?
